text: hi everyone
bestinybrixtano here the internet's
busiest music nerd and it's time for a
review of this new
weekend album dawn fm this is a brand
new lp from vocalist and songwriter
producer to abel tesfaye aka the weeknd
his fifth studio album so far as it
follows his hit record after hours from
2020 which saw him make a more
transformative shift toward a classic
synth pop sound a real 80s vibe which
abel is far from being the first artist
to try to recapture but he certainly did
put his own spin on it creating some
pretty huge ripples in the mainstream
with some of his pop boy contemporaries
trying to recreate the success of hit
songs like save your tears and blinding
lights and now reflecting on it even
though after hours was a significant
change of pace stylistically for abel
dawn fm sounds like the completion of
that transition it's also proof after
hours wasn't just restless creativity
driving abel in some random direction
after all recently on twitter he did
make mention of the fact that uh we are
in the midst of a new trilogy now with
this record being the second part of it
so yeah after hours was in fact laying
the groundwork for something that is now
bigger more conceptual dawn fm is really
signifying the dawn of a new era for
able and the record i think is grander
in scope than some people are giving it
credit for too abel's not just dabbling
in a retro pop style on this record but
bringing it back with a sleek modern
punch with more attention to stylistic
detail too there are some passages
instrumentally on this lp that remind me
of acts like depeche mode or
orchestral maneuvers in the dark also
the musical backbone of out of time is
based on a classic japanese city pop
sample too abel's love of daft punk and
dance music is shining brighter on this
record than it ever has in the past two
even on starboy he also hasn't been
nodding this hard in the direction of
michael jackson
since he dropped his cover of dirty
diana like 10 years ago finally you can
really hear two of the most consistent
names involved in the writing side and
production side on this record are max
martin pop legend max martin and daniel
lopatin aka one of tricks point never
and with those two on your side how
could you not end up with an album that
has fantastic soundcraft a dark vibe a
concept but also hits hard like some of
the biggest pop anthems of the 2000s i
know this may sound pretentious but dawn
fm is not just a pop album but a pop
experience at least that's clearly what
it's shooting for and i think this
record mostly achieves that goal with
loads of vivid cinematic instrumentation
a kind of cute cultish dystopian radio
theme hosted by none other than jim
carrey there's also a flow to this track
list that sees many of its songs seguing
into each other too it's pretty clear
abel and daniel were looking at this
project as holistically as possible and
the result may be that there's less
single power on this record than there
was on after hours but i still think it
made for a better overall experience
especially in the first half which is
packed with highlights there's the
entrancing opener that sounds like i'm
about to join some kind of electro cult
then we get the equally moody and groovy
gasoline where able delivers these uh
kind of deep semi-deadpan lead vocals on
his verses which is a refreshing change
of pace and sounds like something out of
a track you'd hear playing at an old
goth club following this we have the
bittersweet how do i make you love me
which has some really sugary chord
changes playing against a lot of
detailed synth work builds up a lot of
tension before we hit this righteous
galloping chorus the lead single to this
album take my breath i thought was okay
on first listen the chorus really popped
but i wasn't entirely sold on the song's
lyrics i saw the fire in your eyes i saw
the fire when i look into your eyes i
don't think is like the strongest
starting line but i do love the extended
dance version of the song on the album
the driving grooves and daft punk love
ring through beautifully and it just
makes the core song feel that much more
gratifying when it does eventually hit
now does sacrifice not have one of the
sickest grooves of the year
isn't it like the first month of the
year
i will end you
the vocal melodies on this track also
call back to
you know very mj thriller era kind of
vibe but combine that with some very
lush and glorious french house the
heart-wrenching quincy jones interlude
on the record ushers in a different
sound and vibe in the track list things
really begin to smooth out
instrumentally we get more ballads the
song out of time is beautiful just pure
bliss city pop magic all over the place
this sound this style is somehow just a
perfect fit in this track list able also
complements it with just some great
vocal work too and a story about being
too late to uh recapture a love i'm also
loving the song here we go again with
tyler the creator the track very much
about being in a better place than your
ex is and kind of laughing at their
position while you're riding high and
being successful with a better person
now tyler lyrically backs up the total
a-hole attitude of the song with uh
mentions of a prenup there's a lot of
kanye energy coming off his verse even
if it is short now from this point i
think dawn fm does continue to dish out
good tracks but i don't think the flow
is as steady in its footing as
everything else up until this point the
track every angel is terrifying does add
to the radio concept of the record but
not really in a complementary way with
the stunning build in the first half of
the track eventually giving way to a
jarring transition into this pretend
radio ad that sounds like something
really hokey out of a bad black mirror
episode meanwhile starry eyes does have
some great huge panoramic synthesizers
some spotlet vocals as well but the song
is a little one note very middling the
whole track feels like a mere extension
of the song just before it and the lil
wayne appearance in the second half of i
heard you're married is really one of
his worst features in a minute his flow
does not complement the beat at all and
i really could have gone the rest of my
life without hearing i bet he treats you
like virgin mary you like it dirty and
i'm dirty hairy like [ __ ] that wear the
love at tell hubby i'll kill him no
hubcap so
yeah these tracks are not uh
the best but in the second half of the
lp we still do get the very groovy best
friends which might have one of the
louder and more one-dimensional
instrumentals on the record but still
there's a lot of detail in the lyrics on
this one the sexual and emotional
tension is huge with the track being
about the push and pull of a toxic
relationship needing to get out of it
but still wanting uh that friendship
still wanting that sexual connection too
but uh then as you kind of get closer to
that uh friend zoning somebody still
wanting that physical connection uh
you're feeling that pull back into the
relationship once again then the need
for distance returns it's just sourness
all around there's a chilling chorus on
don't break my heart that hits pretty
hard too and then finally less than zero
dishes out some peppy and bubbly synth
pop that finishes things on a
more positive upbeat note and i think
sets things up for the next section of
this current trilogy the acoustic
transition at the end is quite nice too
and i like jim carrey's outro on the
record i mean the the dystopian poetry
he brings to the table is uh pretty
effective so yeah overall dawn fm i
thought was a very good very impressive
pop album with the dynamic versatile and
conceptual production there's a
grandiosity to it as well again i think
this album sounds like a movie abel is
very much world building on this project
and doing so very well he has some great
songwriting here some cool vocal
switch-ups here and there as well i
think the first half is quite a bit
stronger than the second half of the
record but still as an overall
experience i think dawn fm is quite good
and easily going to be one of the better
pop records we're going to hear this
year i'm feeling a strong 7 to a light 8
on this one tran position have you given
this album a listen did you love it did
you hate it what would you rate it
you're the best you're the best what
should i review next hit the like if you
like please subscribe and please don't
cry hit the bell as well over here next
to my head it's another video you can
check out hit that up or the link to
subscribe to the channel and uh yeah the
weekend dawn fm
forever
